problem_text: A permutation group on a set Ω is called sharply doubly transitive if for any two pairs (α, β) and (γ, δ) of elements of Ω such that α ≠ β and γ ≠ δ, there is exactly one element of the group taking α to γ and β to δ. Does every sharply doubly transitive group possess a non-trivial abelian normal subgroup? A positive answer is well known for finite groups. V. D. Mazurov
answer: No, not every (E. Rips, Y. Segev, K. Tent, J. Europ. Math. Soc., 19, no. 10 (2017), 2895–2910).
